text: thank you for your invitation I'm very happy to be here and indeed um we're in
a period of uh exacerbated um geopolitical conflicts and what I'd like
to talk about is how these conflicts actually shape cyerspace how it changes
the environment you work in and you actually live in Um just to start with
an example on May 30th at 2:43 in the afternoon the internet went down in the
city of Kersonen for nearly an hour And at that time uh Russian troops literally
at gunpoint forced local internet operators to disconnect from Ukraine's
network and reconnect through Moscow Why because for Russia controlling the roots
of the internet has become a strategic priority in order to be able to control
information And that's actually something that was clearly stated in the two uh 2019 law on the sovereign
internet the runet But another example is that on February 27 2022 3 days into
the war Ukraine government issued a decree under martial law ordering network operators to block 600 Russian
autonomous systems in Ukraine Uh which was sort of a first in the country's
history And then the next day um the government of Ukraine the deputy prime
minister issued a request to internet governments organizations asking them to
impose strict technical sanctions against the Russian Federation blocking its access to the global internet in
response to the war of aggression uh towards Ukraine and its citizens And
later in March private internet carriers announced their intention to withdraw from Russia Um Conent and Lemon for
example decided to discontinue their services in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine So this is part of a wider trend
Uh it's the turn to the infrastructures of the internet uh for geopolitical
control This is in line with the increased militarization of cyerspace and now the weaponization of the public
core of the internet So we do have strategies of territorial control both
physical and digital that tend to shape the form of cyerspace and also threaten
its very model of resilience Now of course the internet is a very dynamic
environment and it changes all the time That's one of its constant features Um
but and and like most networks it initially went uh through phases of
decentralization and then recentralization reconentration at different levels of analysis But what
we're observing now it's two different trends um that are happening at the same
time On the one hand we observe a dynamic of fragmentation along national
borders at the initiative of some states uh in the name of national security And
what we're seeing is a number of states that try to restore control at their
borders in what they perceive that their own share of cyerspace Uh and this is
really guided by concerns over digital sovereignty and that involves
controlling the the path that data takes because it offers a number of strategic
advantages such as the ability to selectively block traffic um to spy on
it to divert it This form of fragmentation is often called the bulcanization of cyerspace um and that
would undermine the free flow of data and the resilience of the internet That
first trend tends to focus all the political attention Now there's a second trend uh that is less visible at a
higher level of abstraction Um and this time it's guided by market forces and by
performance um which is the concentration of data traffic around a
few major operators in data routing and a few large major platforms that we call
hyperscaler And this dynamic of concentration is largely invisible
outside a community of technical experts And it also leads to a form of
fragmentation along commercial lines And it could also raise issues of free flow
of information of resilience and definitely really thorny issues uh
around uh digital sovereignty These issues are why are they important
because they also raise governance issues um such as the resilience of the internet As we know centralization tends
to create points of vulnerability Um it also impacts the number of alternative
routes available at the summit of the internet But it also has strong impacts on human rights and geopolitical risks
that I will talk about such as strategic dependencies that aren't known or not very well known um such as the ability
to conduct internet shutdown So there is a coercision dimension um to this type
of power or the ability to filter sensor um traffic or uh surveil its content So
today I would like to address both uh those trends Um we've already published
a number of research on the dynamic of fragmentation along national border The dynamic of concentration around a few uh
giant platforms and internet routing operators is still work in progress Um
but um uh I uh that's definitely where I would
like to go next So on the first um dynamic um I'm running this project
called matting mapping internet routes for geopolitics and this is super important because the uh it's difficult
to do geopolitics and be an analyst in geopolitics nowadays if we don't understand the digital dimension of all
these conflicts Um because now every single conflict has a cyber or digital
dimension whether we're talking about the internet products or whether we're talking about um disinformation uh every
aspect um that requires advanced uh interdisciplinary work which is what
we've been doing so uh so far Um and that requires also to get the technical
uh community involved in this research to help us identify what is strategic
and what is leveraged in uh the cyber dimension for these conflicts So um this
study is at the inter intersection of several bodies of um literature because
we're trying to bring a methodological contribution through innovative methodologies to understand and
represent the geography of cyerspace and it's very difficult to represent it
clearly for people who don't understand very well the technical aspects and that's definitely where we're trying to
go because uh we think it's important to bring issues into policy circles Um we
also bringing an empirical contribution through the elaboration of case studies and we have PhD students working on
Pakistan West Africa uh China um North
Canada all kinds of places but also a theoretical contribution How does
geopolitics shape cyberspace how can the observation of cyerspace uncover
strategies that are otherwise invisible of territorial control of cyerspace uh
how do the social technical actors involve align or not with states to help
them achieve their strategic goals and how can all these internet
infrastructures be leveraged or weaponized for geopolitical
control So in order to observe these phenomenons we develop a methodology uh
with um my colleague Cavis Salamaton uh using a BGP platforms So the our
platform uh captures and processes the path updates that are advertised by the
routers running BGP Um and the platform generates every minute a full graph of
all autonomous systems relationship uh using publicly available routing data
This real-time snapshot contains about 80,000 89,000 nodes and over 200 links
knowing that the nodes uh you're going to see are the autonomous systems and the leaks or BGP routes and then we use
a oint uh methodologies to find out the names associated with each autonomous
systems where it's registered where it's located how many IP sets of addresses
it's um it manages and then uh we sp uh we apply
algorithms to uh these graphs in order to spatialize them so that uh the closer
the nodes the more links they share with each other and also to identify the centrality of some nodes meaning that
the bigger ones are the one that concentrate uh the highest number of shortest path So the first study we did
was on Iran and um as you saw on Iran in Iran on November 19 2019
um in the space of 24 hours Iran managed to selectively block most of its traffic
to and from the global internet But as early as June 2018 our team had produced
a graph demonstrating that Iran actually had the the possibility to do it So how
did we do that we first look at the architecture of connectivity of the gold regions and uh their uh neighbors And in
this graph you have all the autonomous systems of the Gulf regions and uh their
neighbors international neighbors And this figure offers a representation that
shows that Iran's network is clearly on the margin of the graph because it is um
it has a limited number of interconnections with other Gulf countries but also with international
autonomous systems Um and uh this means that Iran is only connected to a limited
number of nodes But we also see that it has a limited number of gateways uh we
then studied more precisely and um I put a more recent graph here but we're going to go back to 2018 and the very first
graph that we did which is a simplified representation of the architecture of
connectivity of uh Iran and we only kept into the graph um the transit uh
autonomous systems and what we were able to show here is autonomous systems in
Iran and the foreign autonomous systems they were connected with And when you
look at this graph you show that there are only three main points of entry to
and from the global internet with Iran's network And all of these three
autonomous systems that you're seeing on the graph uh it's ITC TIC and IPM um are
under the control of the government um there is a lack of connectivity
um between Iran and most the neighborhood countries as we've seen and if you look at the major international
autonomous systems uh most of them are from u uh the uh major western um
countries Um so you see this form it's it's a bit like um like a tree uh and we
have real gatekeepers that explain uh that we have a sort of bottleneck and
that explains that because of this architecture Iran was able slice by slice to decide which traffic to connect
and which traffic not to connect And I forgot to mention when you look at what
happened here um you have a part of the traffic that kept going through during
the shutdown uh which is the traffic which is essential to the countries mostly banking transactions and and so
on So that also explains why during this
shutdown uh the domestic internet uh keep kept functioning because it was cut
only from and to the global internet and that's part of a choice that was made uh
by Iran in the way it redesigned the architecture of connectivity in order to
be able to achieve exactly that which is having a tight control of the
interconnectivity ity to uh the international internet while having a
domestic and functioning uh network Uh and we mapped only the network of Iran
Here we looked at the the um architecture of connectivity within the
domestic network and we see uh that um it is rather rich uh and not very
centralized uh so therefore uh very resilient We also see that the number of
autonomous systems uh after 2009 sharply increased in Iran And this was part of
the strategy the cyber strategy that Iran put in place after the stuckset attack in order to protect itself from
being disconnected to the internet by great powers It totally reorganized its
um network uh in order to keep it going even under attack Um and what's we're
seeing is that the even though we have a number of central autonomous systems um
it is not fully centralized and the most important within the domestic networks are not the same that are the
gatekeepers to the global internet So in order to uh verify this we run measures
of uh complexity to uh show the centralization of the network So the
complexity score um quantifies the difficulty to control the network within a country given the number of IP
addresses um than the diversity of their administrators So the higher the score
the most difficult it is to control the network And in countries where most IP
addresses are managed by just a few autonomous systems there is a limited number of path and operators and the
network has a complexity uh that is low So the network is easy to control Um but
it creates major uh vulnerabilities Um in countries where there's a high number
and great diversity of autonomous systems there are a lot more path So the network is harder to control but it's
very resilient And we see um the complexity score of uh Iran is rather
high compared to most of his neighbors But what's interesting too is that um it
remained complexed u between 2011 and 2019 while in many other countries of
the region the level of complexity dropped to facilitate uh control We also
um completed this metric with the points of control to measure the centralization of the network and that score represents
the medible number of autonomous systems that are required to connect 90% of all
IP addresses of a country So the higher the value the less centralized is the
network and the lower the value the easier it is to control the network So
if you look at the points of control you see as well that Iran has a complex network compared with other countries of
the region uh and that its complexity has been maintained or has increased
while other countries have a tendency to reduce it and um so what's interesting is um
you take Turkey and Israel for example they have levels of complexity but the control value is much slower than Iran
So they're more centralized and easier to control And then other countries like
Saudi Arabia um and Egypt are highly centralized which means that their
network is also vulnerable to congestion and to possible failures or cyber
attacks against these points of vulnerability So you see that in Iran the emphasis was really on uh
controlling the borders being able to isolate their network uh from the global
internet to make it at the same time uh internally robust and Iran can modulate
its level of international connectivity according to its interests according to
its strategic objectives according also to um the situation politically Um so
it's sort of managed to achieve um uh to
to reconcile strategic goals that seem pretty conflicting like having this
self- sustaining and resilient domestic network with tight control at its
border That's um a view of uh 2000 uh 2023 And you see that this strategy is
even pushed further since now there are only two uh points of control which is
the old network academic network IPM uh and uh TIC which is the main gateway to
Iran's network Uh so here again we only kept um autonomous systems in the craft
that actually do transit Um and you see on the left of the graph all the
international autonomous systems that they are connected to Uh and the number is much more limited than it was in 2018
or even 2014 um in the crafts we did That is exactly what allows Iran to
uh run internet curfews And that's what they did uh to suppress the protest

which was sort of sitting between both worlds And then the increasing distance

So the question is whether we had a digital front line that was consistent with the military front line and in
order to do that we conducted trace routes So we sent packets from a probe
um to um Kev and um so we had we selected two cities Kersonen and
Nonakovka that at the time was occupied and we sent um data packets um to Kev
and each of these two cities there are less than 50 miles apart um but they're

destination uh in Kev from Novakovka It goes through several autonomous systems
in Russia Then it goes to the UK before it eventually lands in Ukraine and in
Kee whereas from Kersonen it takes a rather direct route So we have a sort of
a consistency So um for this first part of the study um and this has really
important policy implications in terms of first uh is this acceptable to
weaponize the public core given that this form of fragmentation can create
resilience issues uh for the entire internet Um the more the internet is
centralized around a few uh nodes the less alternative routes you have Um if
there is only one gateway that carries international transit for Iran as opposed to all potential autonomous
systems carrying traffic then uh you have a decrease in the number of routes
and there are much easier to control u by different countries It's also um
raises important issues not only in terms of systemic risk but also human

sanctions can backfire They can sort of also contribute to trap populations into

the internet or to block traffic or to surveil traffic So these are very important issues that I believe we
should be discussing in policy circles Now the um second part uh that I wanted
to talk about is this issue of contraction of um the internet Um the
internet has been able to grow and develop very quickly because it is decentralized and the number of
autonomous systems has grown very fast from 40,000 to uh 80,000 active
autonomous systems within a decade uh but what we observe is only a small
portion of autonomous systems play a central role role in uh routing data

geographical imbalances and a dynamic of concentration of traffic through a
limited number of routing giants uh which leads to the shrinking of the
internet and with major um policy implications that I will talk about
later Um this concentration is largely the result of a larger trend of flattening
of the internet which is driven uh by the evolution of the traffic link to
giant content platforms And what we're seeing is that these giant platforms
such as Google um Meta Amazon content delivery networks they have emerged in
the data routing landscape and they now develop their own routing infrastructure
So they're pulling their own submarine cables deploying their own intercontinental continental routing
architectures So they increasingly bypass traditional intermediary routing
operators and this also fragments um the internet uh along commercial lines and
participates to what we can call the flattening of the internet uh it's the same handful of private uh giants that
dominate now both the infrastructure of the internet but also its most popular
services and applications So they're gaining control over on the one hand the
content but also the means of delivering the content and um they're becoming sort of
their own internet backbone So this is largely driven by the evolution of the
traffic They concentrate a very large part of the traffic due to their massive number of users Uh we're seeing that the
top uh according to the latest SandVine report the top eight brands generate
more internet traffic than everyone else combined Uh and if you just take Alphabet and Meta it's 39% of the fixed
traffic and 42% of mobile So that changes the shape of the internet with
important consequences and we have a sort of double paradox with regards to
resilience because the first one is this new architecture decreases the load of
internet on the internet backbone because through the cach's point of presence the traffic u becomes more
regional Uh so that sort of decreases the load on the internet backbone It's
lowers the risks of congestion It's better for the planet It's a better resilience for the end users But the
problem is these platforms they do not intend to become central players um uh
for routing They first and foremost expend to deliver their own content to their users And as they bypass
traditional routing operators that means loss of revenue for them Uh and these
intermediaries are still needed to convey the rest of the traffic across the internet But these intermediaries
either they go out of business or uh they merge with uh bigger ones So that
contributes to the huge concentration around a handful of major routing operators So you have better resilience
at the level of end users but it a decrease in the number of alternative routes at uh the core of the internet at
the summit of the hierarchy hierarchy and all the traffic goes through a handful of global operators and that
leads to concentration and that's the second paradox because on the one hand
concentration is what may allow major platforms to invest in the best talents
and in the best technology to provide top quality services But at the same
time this hyper concentration creates also a point of vulnerability and uh
when an incident occurs uh as was the case with Facebook in 2021 the entire
traffic of their users data is interrupted with major consequences on their activities So we're going to see
more incidents that have huge consequences because of this level of
concentration or at least that's a possibility The problem is as citizens
of Europe uh or any kind of citizen we don't really have a way to understand
these vulnerabilities because there is no transparency at all on how these
platforms route uh their data They sort of privatize the roots of the internet
So all their routing infrastructure internally for these platforms is not u
publicly observable uh and therefore there's a lack of understanding of the multiple dependencies we might be
exposed to The problem in the modern internet we often observe that failures are um sometimes called by largecale
physical destructions like floods like major climate events but very often
they're linked to the complexity of the network and often unknown mutual dependencies uh with applications
depending on many services So the flattening of the internet has increased
uh these unknown dependencies uh and we're growing more and more
reliant on gigantic platforms that are handling traffic in a way that is not
transparent These trends of course can have long-term implications Um this
virtual integration leads to a set of global monopolies uh that aggregate uh
